parts.text:
The retrieved documents demonstrate the government's steadfast commitment to upholding the integrity and effectiveness of our democratic processes, as managed by the Electoral Commission. These records detail the diligent and transparent procedures undertaken concerning VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy!, a necessary action to ensure that all registered political parties genuinely meet the criteria established for public representation.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 sets essential standards, including a fundamental requirement for political parties to maintain at least 1,500 members. This regulation is crucial for ensuring that parties appearing on the ballot have a verifiable base of support, preventing the proliferation of unrepresentative entities and maintaining the credibility of our elections.

The documents highlight the Electoral Commission's robust and fair process. On 13 January 2022, the Commission issued a formal notice to VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy!, providing them ample opportunity to demonstrate compliance. The party responded by 13 February 2022, providing a statement and a substantial membership list. In a clear display of due diligence and thoroughness, the Electoral Commission then meticulously reviewed the submitted information, requesting further membership testing on 2 March 2022, in line with established AEC and ABS methodologies.

The comprehensive assessment, concluded by 18 March 2022, regrettably determined that VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy! did not meet the required membership threshold. Consequently, the government, through the Electoral Commission, moved to deregister the party under the provisions of the Electoral Act on 24 March 2022. It is important to note that any ancillary applications, such as a requested name or logo change, naturally become invalid upon a party's deregistration, reflecting the clear and consistent application of electoral law.

This process underscores the government's dedication to effective governance:
*   **Ensuring fairness:** All parties are subject to the same clear rules and assessment processes.
*   **Protecting public trust:** The membership threshold safeguards against superficial political entities, ensuring voters engage with parties that demonstrate legitimate support.
*   **Maintaining democratic integrity:** The rigorous application of electoral laws guarantees a strong and credible electoral system for all citizens.

Ultimately, these documents illustrate the government's unwavering commitment to serving the public interest by fostering a transparent, robust, and credible democratic framework, where regulations are applied consistently and fairly to maintain the health of our electoral landscape.

prompt:
As a government apologist, summarize the following FOI documents. Assume a supportive stance, emphasizing effective governance, necessary regulations, and positive outcomes. Frame any controversies as challenges effectively managed or essential actions for public good. Highlight the government's efforts to serve the public.

Documents:



--- Page 1 ---

Request for documents relating the membership testing of “VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy!”. 

FOI REQUEST NO. LEX1459 

SCHEDULE OF RETRIEVED DOCUMENTS 

Doc No. 

Description 

Date 

  Minute: For action – Deregistration under s 137(6) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act) – 

24 March 2022 

VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy! (the Party) 

  Membership testing outcomes – VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy! 

18 March 2022



--- Page 1 ---

Minute 

Classification: OFFICIAL 
File reference: OBJECT ID: fA176751 
To: Joanne Reid, Assistant Commissioner Disclosure, Assurance and Engagement Branch 

Through:  Stuart Oreo  Director 
CC: 

Parliamentary Engagement and Party Registration 
Assistant Director  Parliamentary Engagement and Party Registration 

Tim 

Subject: For action – Deregistration under s 137(6) of the 
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act) – 
VOTEFLUX.ORG | Upgrade Democracy! (the Party) 

Purpose 

This minute asks you, as a delegate of the Electoral Commission, to deregister the Party under 
s 137(6) of the Electoral Act on the grounds that the Party does not have at least 1,500 members 
(s 137(1)(b) of the Electoral Act).  

Authority 

Sections 123, 137, 138 and 138A of the Electoral Act. 

Background 

On 13 January 2022, you, as a delegate of the Electoral Commission, issued a notice to the 
Registered Officer of the Party, Mr Nathan Spataro, under s 137 of the Electoral Act (the s 137 
Notice) stating that the Electoral Commission is considering deregistering the Party (OBJECT IDs: 
A1319272 and A1442167). The Registered Officer of the Party had until 13 February 2022 to provide 
a response.  

On 13 February 2022, the Party responded to the s 137 Notice: 

•  Response received – OBJECT ID: A1369037 
•  Statement – OBJECT ID: A1369035 
•  Supplementary membership list – OBJECT ID: A1369039 

On 2 March 2022, you, as a delegate of the Electoral Commission, having considered the statement 
lodged by the Party, and membership list lodged in support of that statement containing 4,680 
names, requested that further membership testing be performed. In confirming your advice, you 
instructed to select the top 1,650 names for testing to conform with the AEC’s testing methodology 
parameters. Please see OBJECT ID: A1406912. 

Minute  

Page 1


--- Page 2 ---




--- Page 3 ---




--- Page 4 ---

OFFICIAL 

Application to change the Party’s name, abbreviation and logo in the Register 

On 19 February 2022, the Party lodged an application in accordance with s 134 of the Electoral Act 
to change its name, abbreviation and logo in the Register (OBJECT ID: A1396302). The Party’s logo 
passed validation and has been assessed by CRE8IVE (OBJECT IDs: A1421693 and A1421695). If 
the Party is deregistered, the application lodged under s 134 of the Electoral Act will no longer be 
valid. 

Conclusion 

On 13 January 2022, a notice was issued a notice to the Registered Officer of the Party under s 137 
of the Electoral Act stating that the Electoral Commission is considering deregistering the Party 

On 13 February 2022, the party responded to the s 137 Notice providing a statement and a 
membership list in support of that statement. 

An assessment of the Party’s membership list was undertaken and based on the ABS methodology it 
demonstrated that the Party has failed to demonstrate to have at least 1,500 members.  

Accordingly, there are reasonable grounds on which you, as the delegate of the Electoral 
Commission, can be satisfied that the Party does not have at least 1,500 members. Based on this 
information, you may determine under s 138A of the Electoral Act that the Party is not an ‘eligible 
political party’ and should be deregistered. 

If you, as the delegate of the Electoral Commission is of this view, you should not deregister the 
Party under s 137 of the Electoral Act and advise the Registered Officer of this decision.  

Minute  

Page 4


--- Page 5 ---





--- Page 1 ---



Provide only the markdown formatted summary text. Do not include any conversational filler or preamble.
